title: Manchester United boss Jose Mourinho admits to mixed emotions over impending Morgan Schneiderlin exit
text:
Sport Manchester United boss Jose Mourinho admits to mixed emotions over impending Morgan Schneiderlin exit The Frenchman is set to join Everton in a £22million deal in the next 48 hours, after the two clubs finally agreed a fee Share Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now Jose Mourinho speaks about Morgan Schneiderlin exit Share this video Get Manchester United FC   
Manchester United boss Jose Mourinho has admitted that he has mixed emotions over Morgan Schneiderlin's impending departure to Everton. 
The Toffees have been in negotiations with United since before Christmas for the Frenchman and the clubs have finally agreed a fee. 
A breakthrough in talks was made on Tuesday evening and Schneiderlin is due at Finch Farm in the next 48 hours for a medical. 
It is understood the initial fee for Schneiderlin is £22million, and could rise to £24million with add-ons, which would be just £1million short of the figure United paid Southampton in July 2015. Schneiderlin has played just 11 minutes in the Premier League this term (Photo: Reuters) 
“Before the match Mr Woodward told me [it’s] almost there, so I don’t have ‘he is there’, I have ‘almost there’” said Mourinho. 
“So I’m sad, I’m happy. I’m sad because I like him, I’m sad because he could be an option for us in the long season. 
“I’m happy because this is what he wants, he wants to play, he wants to play every game, he wants to be an important player in the team. 
“So if this is what he wants, I’m happy for a very good professional." Mourinho has mixed emotions over Schneiderlin's departure (Photo: Tom Purslow) 
Schneiderlin had seen first-team opportunities short on the ground under Mourinho this term, featuring in the Premier League for just 11 minutes. 
The 27-year-old knew he is down the pecking order and has been keen to reunite with his former Southampton boss Ronald Koeman at Goodison Park. 
West Brom were also interested in the Frenchman, and had prepared to make him the club's highest-paid player. 
But they were unable to agree a fee with United, seeing an £18million offer turned down.
